urn:contentItem:5FCG-6191-F0J6-J0MB-00000-00FORESTRY Corporation of NSW will carry out a series2015-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 6FORESTRY Corporation of NSW will carry out a seriesTracey Fairhurst

FORESTRY Corporation of NSW will carry out a series of hazard reduction burns over the next two months in Bago State Forest and Ballengarra State Forest near Wauchope, and in Cairncross State Forest south of Telegraph Point and near Red Hill.

Forest Protection Manager Karel Zejbrlik said hazard reduction burns were a key part of Forestry Corporation's preparation for fire season each year.

"Fire season has just wrapped up for another year, which means it's time to start preparing for next summer," Mr Zejbrlik said.

"There's a narrow window of opportunity to safely complete hazard reduction burns, when it's not too hot or damp and the wind conditions limit the impact of smoke on neighbours, so we will be taking advantage of favourable conditions over the coming months to reduce fuel in local forests.

"While Forestry Corporation fire fighters will carefully monitor all controlled burns to ensure they stay within cleared containment lines, we do ask people to pay attention to any signs in the forest or instructions from staff and stay away from any burning or recently burnt areas for their own safety.

"Forest fire fighters play an important role fighting fires in the region's state forests, but fire prevention is a fundamental part of our role. We expect to complete over 1000 hectares of hazard reduction burns on the mid north coast this year to protect local communities from the risk of wildfires.

"Over the coming months we will also be investing in training fire fighting staff, maintaining and upgrading equipment, improving key forest roads for rapid access and manning fire towers to aid rapid fire detection and quick response."

Forestry Corporation is responsible for more than 2.2 million hectares of native and planted forests and has been formally involved in fire-fighting in NSW for almost 100 years.

urn:contentItem:5VG8-N541-F0J6-J1SB-00000-00Fairy grass concerns continue for Clear Lake community | Photos, Video2019-02-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisFairy grass concerns continue for Clear Lake community | Photos, VideoJade Bate

CLEAR Lake residents say they are fed up with lack of action from government bodies around the town's growing fairy grass problem.

In November 2018, Parks Victoria did an assessment of the problem and slashed fairy grass at Clear Lake. The grass grows inside the lake and around the Clear Lake Reserve.

Parks Victoria describes fairy grass as "a native blown grass which colonises in damp, bare areas and germinates as soon as temperature and moisture levels are suitable".

Clear Lake is home to about 40 residents and the town has faced problems with fairy grass since the late 1980s.

Resident Trevor Watson has lived in the town his whole life and said the problem subsided when the grass was burned off.

"The first year it got really bad, there was still water in the lake and the grass all around the tree line. We burned around the trees. Then the next year the lake dried up and we burned inside it," he said.

Related: Clear Lake fairy grass influx causes fire concerns

Parks Victoria, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, the Country Fire Authority and Clear Lake residents co-ordinated the burn-off.

"From then on we didn't have a problem with the fairy grass until 2015 when it came back. When Parks Victoria slash it, all it's doing is putting the seeds back on the floor of the lake," Mr Watson said.

Residents Jen and Craig Giggins said their house was inundated with fairy grass a few weeks ago, and most residents had experienced the same situation.

Mrs Giggins said the grass was "more than eight feet high" in some areas.

"It's heartbreaking. It gets into all the sheds, the chicken coops, up the fences, over the air-conditioners. It comes into your house and is impossible to weed out of the garden," Mrs Giggins said.

"We only just finished cleaning up our place from the last time it happened and then six weeks later it was back."

Mr Giggins said Parks Victoria had not contacted residents about conducting further assessments since its November assessment.

Related: Opinions split over fairy grass solutions

"Parks Victoria keep telling us that they are monitoring the situation. We have all contracted Parks Victoria individually about different problems," Mr Giggins said.

"Every year the fairy grass season rolls around and they just seem to ignore it. We keep getting told it's a huge fire risk, but nothing gets done."

In 2002 a build up of fairy grass caught on fire at Dock Lake Reserve, which threatened people who were at the reserve playing sport. About 225 hectares of land and the Taylors Lake Football Clubrooms were destroyed.

Clear Lake farmer Lachie Wilson said he was concerned about the fire danger risk of fairy grass at his property.

"On the most recent Total Fire Ban day (on January 29) when it was more than 40 degrees and there were 50km/h winds blowing straight out the lake, if a pilot light or powerline had sparked then you have no break between the grass and the house. The grass is very combustible and can move around so easily," he said.

"There are paddocks around here that are covered in fairy grass. I don't know how we're going to go about sowing in them. It was getting into the headers last time and were overheating."

Parks Victoria area chief ranger Zoe Wilkinson said fairy grass had appeared at many lakes and waterway across the Wimmera this summer.

"This summer, Parks Victoria has been in regular contact with some of the people living near Clear Lake about the impact of fairy grass blowing from the lake-bed and onto their properties," she said.

"It is a difficult grass to manage, as treatments such as herbicide and burning have been found to result in an increased density of the fairy grass in later seasons because the treatment also removes competing vegetation.

"Local evidence suggests the best treatment is to allow the natural process of vegetation succession with minimal human intervention. Importantly, Clear Lake also contains registered Aboriginal heritage sites which must be protected when considering any treatment of this native grass."

She said Forest Fire Management Wimmera would assess the Clear Lake fairy grass as part of its fuel management strategy for 2019-20, alongside the CFA and Parks Victoria.

"These will include the local community in these conversations," she said.

While you're with us, you can now receive updates straight to your inbox twice weekly from the Wimmera Mail-Times. To make sure you're up-to-date with all the news from across the Wimmera, sign up below.

urn:contentItem:5PHG-D3N1-F0JP-W3T8-00000-00Street Watch2017-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Street Watch

1 CRANBOURNE Dozens of machetes and swords have been seized from a home in Cranbourne after a man was allegedly found selling the weapons on Facebook. Narre Warren police executed a warrant about 6.30pm on September 12 at a house in Latrobe St and discovered the cache of weapons. Among the 29 prohibited and controlled weapons were flick knives, hunting knives, swords and machetes. A 39-year-old Cranbourne man is expected to be charged on summons with possessing and dealing in prohibited and controlled weapons.

2 NARRE WARREN A Narre Warren driver lost control of her car and smashed into her neighbour's house on September 10. The woman, who lived across the road, pulled up to back into her garage but reverse instead and ended up crashing through the garage and into the main bedroom. Nobody was home at the time. Police warned people to drive carefully and pay attention when behind the wheel.

3 EUMEMMERRING Casey detectives are investigating an armed robbery in Eumemmerring on July 30 at 3.45pm. Two men went to the United service station in Princes Highway where they demanded money from the attendant. Police believed the first was armed with a long rifle. The attendant handed over cash from the till. It is believed the men then left in a white four-door VW Golf hatchback. The first man is described as caucasian, aged in his 20s, 165cm - 170cm with a light coloured beard. He was wearing a bandana over his face and mouth, had black hair and was wearing black gloves, light pants, a striped jumper and thongs. The second male had brown hair, slim build and was 177cm. He was aged in his mid 20s, and had tattoos on his right arm. He was wearing a red hoodie and black tracksuit pants. Anyone with information is asked to phone the Narre Warren police station on 9705"3111.

4 HALLAM Fire crews from Hallam were called to a massive blaze that ripped through double-storey shops in Dandenong on September 13. Firefighters were called to the Lonsdale St address just after 1.30am and the building was already well alight when crews arrived on scene. Rostered duty officer Gary Bryant said it was a well-managed fire and crews worked hard to get it under control. Firefighters were also able to rescue a dog from the back of one of the shops, pictured above. An investigation will take place to determine how the fire started.

5 CASEY This year's bushfire season is predicted to start earlier and be worse than usual due to a warm, dry winter and forecasts of a hot summer. CFA chief officer Steve Warrington said firefighters wanted people in bushfire prone areas to be prepared for the worst case scenario. "The outlook suggests that we could be looking at the commencement of a fire season as early as October," Mr Warrington said. "Fire season preparations are well under way." CFA has, along with Forest Fire Management Victoria, brought forward the planned burning program. "We are checking staging areas and landing sites for aircraft across districts as well as providing training on hazardous trees and encouraging our firefighters to do burn over drills," Mr Warrington said. "We're confident that our people are ready to fulfil their important duty protecting lives and property." For information on how to prepare for the fire season, go to cfa.vic.gov.au

"When the weather gets hot, workers get struck down by 'suntanitis'."</p><p> Gravesend in Kent and central London were the hottest places in the UK yesterday with 34C  marginally cooler than the record 38.1C set on Sunday, but still higher than Barbados and Honolulu.</p><p> While many enjoy the heatwave, it has also caused concern across Europe.</p><p> Scorching temperatures threatened to cut output at nuclear power stations, while a forest fire in north-eastern Spain has caused fatalities.</p><p> Five people died in a forest fire in the Catalan region in Spain, with hundreds forced to evacuate their homes.</p><p> In France, where temperatures have hit 40C, the government warned there could be blackouts if electricity production continued to be stretched.</p><p> At emergency talks to try to stave off cuts, it agreed to allow the country's nuclear power plants to pour cooling water back into rivers at a higher temperature than usual to help them meet surging demand.</p><p> Two German states also temporarily raised permitted temperature limits on outflows of cooling water, while Swiss power officials have cut output throughout the summer at their nuclear plants rather than put hotter cooling-off water into the Alpine country's rivers.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XHH-88X1-F0JP-W3FM-00000-00THE FLAME GAME2019-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisGOSSIPPg. 8THE FLAME GAMEAndrew Jefferson

WITH bushfires raging in NSW and Queensland, Vic-torians are bracing for a potentially deadly summer.

With the state still reeling from Black Saturday in 2009, how is our region placed to deal with another catastrophic fire?

As NSW and Queensland burns, some politicians, such as Barnaby Joyce, have pointed the finger at "greenies" by claiming environmental regulations have strangled the ability to manage land and exacerbated the fires.

Most of last season's fires were on public land, which is the responsibility of Forest Fire Management Victoria.

In the Otway District, which takes in Geelong, FFMVic says it is ready and has the ability to respond to emergencies 24 hours, seven days a week.

DELWP Barwon South West acting deputy chief fire officer Steve Pellicano said while the Otway District had received recent rain, there was the possibility of above average fire conditions due to underlying soil dryness coupled with an expected hot and dry -summer.

"It is inevitable fires occur every summer in the Otway District, but the region is well-placed to respond to all emergencies and protect com-munities," Mr Pellicano said.

"We have been preparing for the fire season throughout the year by undertaking planned burning, slashing and mowing vegetation, and maintaining fire access roads to -ensure fast response times." The royal commission into the Black Saturday bushfires, which killed 173 people on February 7, 2009, recommended 5 per cent of Victorian public land be burnt each year.

But planned burning in Victoria declined from more than 125,000ha in 2016-17 to about 74,000ha in 2017-18.

The main arguments against prescribed burning are it does not help reduce the damaging impacts of bushfires, and it causes problems for -biodiversity.

Deb Sparks, from the Centre of Excellence for Prescribed Burning, said prescribed burning was an essential part of bushfire mitigation but the windows for burning were -becoming shorter.

"Recent research conducted in Tasmania and NSW into the windows for prescribed burning under climate change scenarios suggest that the windows are changing," Ms Sparks said.

FFMVic says planned burning in the Otway District over autumn was successful, covering more than 5500ha, mostly around coastal townships.

Mr Pellicano said planned burning was carried out under carefully managed conditions, greatly reducing the impact of bushfires by reducing the amount of fuel.

"This means fires are less intense, making it more likely that our firefighters can contain fires before they impact on people, property and the environment," he said.

"During the autumn planned burning season, FFMVic removed significant amounts of forest fuel around at-risk communities including Lorne and Aireys Inlet. " CFA District 7 operations manager Mick McGuinness, who covers the Geelong -region, said he supported FFMVic's burning operations.

"They engage in both low intensity burns and high intensity burns to reduce the fuel loads to reduce the impact of fire on our townships and communities," Mr McGuinness said.

"If we don't do that, then we're not complying with our Act, which is prevention and suppression of fires.

"If we can reduce fuel loads around the forest interface of our townships then there is a lot higher likelihood of survival in those towns and communities when a bushfire occurs." Throughout October and November, an additional 33 seasonal firefighters joined the local FFMVic workforce, and from next week, more than 150 seasonal and permanent firefighters will be in place.

The Otway District's on-road firefighting fleet com-prises 38 specialised vehicles, including numerous fire -tankers and earthmoving -machinery.

The Sikorsky S61 waterbombing helicopter will arrive at Colac air base in coming weeks, and with a water-carrying capacity of 3000 litres, it will be on call for immediate response to fires across the Otway District.

The district also has access to Victoria's 50-strong aerial firefighting fleet, which is one of the largest and most sophisticated aircraft fleets in the world.

As part of national aircraft arrangements, Victoria can also access NSW and SA-based aircraft when required.

If a major fire does break out, residents like those in the small town of Bannockburn could find themselves on the front line.

With many "townies" buying up lifestyle blocks, the population of Bannockburn is tipped to double from 5750 to 10,018 by 2036.

Each November, like every other council area in CFA District 7, Golden Plains Shire fire prevention officer Matthew Sims travels across the shire issuing fire prevention notices to any property owner whose home poses an unnecessary fire risk.

The works must be completed by early December.

If a property owner fails to comply with the notice, they will be issued with an $1652 -infringement.

Council will also engage a contractor to attend and slash your property on behalf of council.

Golden Plains issued 493 notices this year, 150 more than last year. "We're seeing a lot of high grass in new acreage developments where either houses are under construction, vacant, or recently moved in," Mr Sims said.

"We would love to go around in our first round of -inspections and have 5000 bowling greens, but that's not the case.

"We do get some repeat -offenders.

"It is still green at the -moment but that will only take a few days of hot weather to dry off and be a large risk." Mr McGuinness said the onus was also on residents to do their bit in an emergency.

"We live in one of the three most fire-prone areas in the world, so you can't live in this environment and not be prepared," he said.

"On those severe and -extreme fire danger days, don't be there - it's simple. "You need to move away to survive.

"Have your kit ready, have phone numbers in your mobile phone, have a battery operated radio with you, make sure people know where you're going and move out of those high-profile bush areas where you may lose your life.

"Leave early and don't -return until it's safe."

HISTORICAL FIRES IN OUR REGION

Black Friday, January 13, 1939: Four people died at Barongarook near Colac, 71 across Victoria.

January 8, 1969: 18 people died in and around Lara, 23 people across Victoria. February 16, 1983: Three people died in the Otways and on the Surf Coast, 47 across Victoria.

December 2, 1998: Five Geelong West firefighters died at Linton. January 25-27, 2006: Anakie fires, no deaths.December 25, 2015: The Great Ocean Road bushfires destroyed 116 houses - 98 in Wye River and 18 in Separation Creek, no deaths.

urn:contentItem:5BBY-8TR1-F0JP-W0N4-00000-00Volunteers aid firefight2014-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18Volunteers aid firefightSteven Deare

MORE locals are lending their muscle to firefighting efforts outside of Sydney as bushfires at Bathurst and Oberon continue to burn.

About 20 firefighters from the NSW Rural Fire Service's Warringah Pittwater District have been working 12-hour night shifts to assist local crews at five blazes.

The bushfires began on Sunday and have burned more than 4500ha. However an RFS spokesman yesterday said only one fire -remained of -significance.

This was the Hells Hole fire at Bathurst, which has burned 2,656ha and was still being controlled.

About 60 firefighters, 13 fire trucks and two aircraft have been deployed to try and contain the blaze.

Another fire of concern had been the Dog Rock Forest fire at Oberon, which burned 640ha, but this has been brought under control in recent days.

The other Bathurst fires to be under control were at Redbank (1554ha), Winburndale (330ha) and Linden Park (50ha).

NSWRFS Warringah Pittwater District officer Alex Chesser said volunteers from brigades across the unit had or were assisting "strike teams".

These comprised a fire commander and five tankers which travel to affected areas, usually for five days, to assist local crews.

Mr Chesser said volunteers' roles included firefighting, back-burning and patrol duties.

Most firefighters are staying at a showground in Perthville, outside Bathurst. Mr Chesser said Warringah Pittwater members would continue to assist until the fires were -extinguished. No lives or properties have been lost.Warringah Pittwater members recently travelled to South Australia to assist combating bushfires at the Eden Valley.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-RH30-TXN5-T1DY-00000-00Towering over forests to spot potential infernos2000-01-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Towering over forests to spot potential infernos

STATE Forest workers are gearing up for the summer fire season.

Warmer temperatures have sparked a number of extra precautions throughout the Hunter.

Five forest fire towers will be manned during high fire danger periods to ensure early detection.

The towers provide extensive views over State Forests in the Central Coast, the Watagan ranges, Barrington Tops and Myall Lakes.

Helicopters and fixed-wing aircrafts are on stand-by for water bombing exercises at the first sign of smoke. The aircraft would also be used to `see through' smoke and treetops to locate hotspots using infra-red sensors.

In addition, workers have access to six fire tankers, graders, a dozer and hundreds of kilometres of fire trails.

State Forest fire management officer Paul McBain said a range of services were available to ensure minimal damage.

`Throughout last year we were able to undertake a number of hazard reduction burns aimed at reducing levels of fine fuels in target areas,' Mr McBain said.

`This should help us better manage any wildfires over the summer,' he said.

Residents have been urged to take particular note of dangerous weather periods and obey all fire bans.

Anyone who sees smoke in a State Forest area should call State Forests' Newcastle office on 4927-0977.

On the lookout: State Forests Hunter Region ranger Ross Richards beside a new fire tower in the Watagan Mountains. ¤ Picture by Peter Stoop

urn:contentItem:5B6F-X1S1-F0J6-J2NT-00000-00Shops empty as grass fire takes hold2014-01-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Shops empty as grass fire takes holdSTEPHEN RYAN and ASHLEIGH GLEESON

FIRES sparked up around the region yesterday in the sweltering weather conditions.

Employees working at Toronto shopping strip The Boulevard had to be evacuated after a grass fire and a storage shed caught alight behind the stores.

Smoke started to pour into a number of businesses about 11.40am and it took firefighters more than two hours to extinguish the blaze.

Flight Centre suffered smoke and heat damage.

Police set up a crime scene but investigations had not yet determined if the fire was deliberately lit by last night.

"We had someone rush in and tell us we really needed to get out because there's a grass fire behind the store," NRMA employee Julie McGlinn said.

Rural Fire Service and National Parks firefighters are monitoring a number of blazes in remote areas across the Hunter.

A fire that has burnt 427 hectares of land at Big Oakey Gulley near Stewarts Brook was deemed to be under control yesterday.

A forest fire has burnt out more than 234 hectares of land in the Wollemi National Park south of Martindale Creek and was responsible for a blanket of smoke covering parts of northern Sydney yesterday.

There were also reports of fires at Putty State Forest near Rock Holes Creek and Rhondda Road, Teralba.

A pile of tyres also caught alight at a Tomago storage facility on Foresight Avenue about 2pm.

It took more than an hour for firefighters to bring the blaze under control and a nearby shed suffered some structural damage.

urn:contentItem:5XGB-STN1-JD3N-53PS-00000-00FACING OUR RECKONING2019-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisFPAPg. 10FACING OUR RECKONINGAVA BENNY-MORRISON, LINDA SILMALIS

IT was the bushfire emergency firefighters feared - but expected. Multiple large fires burning across the state, the drought creating dangerous fuel conditions and a strong westerly wind pushing fire danger ratings off the charts.

In one of the most terrifying firefighting days in recent years, three people perished with fears for several others in a firestorm that took many residents by surprise.

An estimated 150 homes, schools and businesses between the Queensland border down to the NSW Mid North Coast are believed to be destroyed with the loss expected to rise as assessment teams move in.

However, the nightmare has only just begun.

The state is now facing up to a dangerous summer of fires as several blazes burning in deep bush edge towards coastal populations.

The next challenge will come on Tuesday with fire crews bracing for conditions on par, if not worse, than conditions that fuelled the unprecedented emergency last week.

NSW Rural Fire Service fire behaviour analyst Simon Heemstra described the upcoming conditions as "very hot, very dry and very windy". "The three are lining up on Tuesday for potentially significant fire weather," he said.

Over the next two days fire crews will be racing the clock to bring as many blazes as they can under control.

But containment efforts will be challenged by a drought-stricken landscape where there is plenty of fuel and no moisture in the soil.

NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons described the resulting fire behaviour as "extraordinary".

"You've got flammability of the fuel, which is seeing extraordinary fire behaviour, fires starting extremely quickly, spreading and burning very intensely," he said.

"And very quickly with spot fire activity doubling or tripling what is normally expected over the fire conditions we have been experiencing." The fuel coupled with gusty winds on Friday created a situation where embers were travelling for more than 10km and starting spot fires. "What we had on Friday was really deep mixing and it was pulling strong winds down and that was giving us that strong gustiness that was fanning the flames," Mr Heemstra explained.

"That provides more heat and energy. Then the embers get higher into the atmosphere and are transported further." In some regions, like Ballina and Armidale, the fire danger ratings on Friday were the highest on record. A decent downpour a week ago had little impact.

"The water sat on the surface and the wind we've had has taken it away and we are back to square one," Mr Heemstra said.

Fire crews were drawing from rivers, ponds and streams when possible and relying heavily on areas where water supply wasn't dire, like Coffs Harbour and the Richmond air force base.

On Friday night, firefighters around the Taree blazes could be heard calling in as properties became engulfed in flames. One volunteer, who earlier called in to say his crew was "under attack", declared: "It's out of control here." Another firefighter spoke of being unable to save homes: "Three houses are gone and we are engaging in property protection, but going to pull out. House is unsaveable." Over at Frasers Creek, a call went out for resources to help a person who was trapped.

"We are going to try and put a defensive perimeter around the property," a volunteer said. "Bridge involved in fire and is unpassable," another said. Not all residents chose to leave their properties.

"There is a property here with 80 per cent of it surrounded by fire," a firefighter said. "The owners do not want to leave." Emergency Services Minister David Elliott thanked the 1300 RFS volunteers and 200 NSW Fire and Rescue and interstate firefighters that were fighting the blazes.

urn:contentItem:5XG8-1KT1-JD34-V351-00000-00Our 'clear fire danger'2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Our 'clear fire danger'

From page 1 Along with other fire and emergency services leaders, he has been asking for Mr Morrison to meet to discuss the "rapidly escalating" risks and "inadequate resourcing" of the emergency services.

Mr Bibby, who has been involved in firefighting since 1971, said the lengthening fire seasons were a danger for teams that used to divide their resources interstate.

"We quite often used to share firefighters around. If someone had a bad season, we would send some firefighters to NSW."

Now he said the overlapping fire seasons could make it very hard to get extra people on the ground.

"The scientists out doing the work are just as frustrated as we are - they have a clear understanding of what's happening, and people are just not listening."

He urged residents to accept there was a "clear and present danger" and to make sure politicians knew how they felt: "We have to get (it) into the federal agenda that we have a problem."

Former Forest Fire Management, Victoria chief fire officer Ewan Waller also signed the letter to the prime minister earlier this year.

He told The Courier one of the reasons he did so was to advocate for more resources to stop fires spreading in the first place.

"It's not just about aircraft, it's not just about bigger and better trucks, it's about prevention," he said.

"The fire problem is going to move into Victoria all too soon. We are all very wary of coming into the summer.

"The fringe areas, the surrounding areas of Ballarat are quite exposed.

"The rural subdivisions and the settlements around it - keeping fires from those is really quite difficult. They are quite vulnerable.

"I am very keen to get more resourcing in fuel management so we can do more slashing and burning off on a far broader area than we are doing now.

"In Enfield (State Forest) and Canadian you need to actively manage the fuels otherwise they will cause you no end of trouble."

He said the Scotsburn fire a few years ago showed how fuel management could help minimise the damage.

Mr Waller said he expected a response to the letter soon and wanted to ensure any action had "bipartisan support".

BREAZE FORUM The BREAZE forum took place on Sunday with local residents and fire experts joining to discuss the "New Bushfire Reality" and the changing nature of our area's fire risk.

Adrian Whitehead, the director of Council and Community Action in the Climate Emergency, was one of the keynote speakers at the forum.

His organisation aims to encourage and support councils to prepare for the climate emergency.

"We know these extreme events are coming and the council should be doing everything it possibly can within its available budget to help the community prepare, adapt and have some resilience for these future fire events that we are going to see," he told The Courier ahead of the event.

He said it would require "some really serious planning" to get the community as ready as they needed to be for future fire seasons.

"What would we do if the worst case scenario occurred?" he asked.

"Are the hospitals prepared? Can they run their generators for long enough?"

He also said the issue needed to be considered as part of a wider planning strategy.

"If you look at the fringe of Ballarat, there is quite a number of urban areas that are abutting pine plantations or natural woodlands," Mr Whitehead said.

"Potentially we might need to step back some of these boundaries, otherwise we might find ourselves in a situation like Canberra where they had pine plantations up to their suburbs when they suffered their horrendous fires in 2003.

"We wait for the next huge event to occur and then we put some things in place. We don't actually plan for what could be much bigger.

"We need to look at the predictions of what climate change will bring us and prepare for those events. It's much more than what we're prepared for now."

Country Fire Authority community safety manager Michael Boatman also spoke at the event. He explained how the hotter climate is making bushfires more frequent and dangerous.

"Across Australia, but particularly in south-east Australia and Victoria the most, there is significant change in weather, particularly in spring," he said.

He said the season had been drier and hotter - by about 1.4 degrees - in the past 40 years.

"The change means we are getting fire seasons that start earlier - we need to be ready in November rather than December," he said.

The second message Mr Boatman was keen to convey was about planning. He said people on the urban fringes - such as Mount Helen, Mount Clear, Buninyong and Invermay - should prepare a plan for themselves and their properties.

He also said new development areas west could be at risk even if they are not surrounded by bush, with running grass fires a potential issue.

"As we saw at Melton in 1985, you can lose 20 or 30 houses at the edge of a development if you don't know what you are going to do."

THE SCIENCE The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, an independent federal government agency, combined with the Bureau of Meteorology, pooled their resources with a website (www.climatechangeinaustralia.gov.au) projecting the likely effects of climate change in Australia.

For the purposes of their modelling, Australia is divided into eight "Natural Resource Management" clusters. Ballarat lies within the Southern Slopes Victoria West sub-cluster.

According to the climate modelling data, says temperatures are almost certain to carry on rising: "More hot days and warm spells are projected with very high confidence. Fewer frosts are projected with high confidence."

"Generally less rainfall in the cool season (winter and spring) is projected with high confidence.

"Changes to summer and autumn rainfall are possible but less clear. Increased intensity of extreme rainfall events is projected, with high confidence."

The data also suggests a "high confidence" that climate change will result in a harsher fire-weather climate in the future.

There was less certainty about its extent: "There is low confidence in the magnitude of the change to fire weather. This depends on the rainfall projection and its seasonal variation."

urn:contentItem:5TGD-6FP1-JD34-V2RC-00000-00NZ gives lessons in dealing with climate change2018-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8NZ gives lessons in dealing with climate changePeter Hannam

Scott Simpson, New Zealand's National Party environment spokesman, stunned a trans-Tasman investment meeting last week by stating that climate action was "too important to be playing politics with".

Or rather, it was the Australian delegates who were shocked, so used are they to the toxic debate in Parliament.

"It made my jaw drop, that's for sure," said Emma Herd, chief executive of the Investor Group on Climate Change.

Also well received was Mr Simpson's comment that it was vital "for all of us and our grandchildren that we have a [climate action] framework that is enduring", coming as it did soon after the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change had issued its latest report warning about the perils of even another half degree of warming.

That Mr Simpson hails from the centre-right opposition party roughly equivalent to our Liberal-National coalition only underscored the contrast between the nations.

New Zealand's major parties, busy trying to thrash out a Zero Carbon Bill by year's end, are dismayed by the absence of similar bipartisanship across the Tasman, James Shaw, climate change minister in the Labour-led government said. "We do tend to look at what's going on in Australia politics, in particular in relation to climate policies, and we think, 'We cannot afford to let this happen in New Zealand'," Mr Shaw said. "It seems like a pretty strong lesson in what not to do."

Despite ditching its main climate and energy policy - the National Energy Guarantee aimed at reducing carbon emissions from the power sector while bolstering the grid and easing prices - the Morrison government insists it can meet Australia's Paris climate commitments.

Even if total emissions were the issue, Kiwis would have more excuse than Australians for doing nothing. Their share of global greenhouse gases is less than 0.2 per cent, or about a eighth of Australia's.

Still, on a per capita basis, both nations have among the world's highest emissions, Mr Shaw said.

Tally the 90-odd nations contributing less than 1 per cent of emissions and you reach almost a third of the global total - larger than China or the US, he said.

"An issue like this is something the whole world has to grapple with," Todd Muller, Mr Shaw's counterpart from the National Party, said.

To remove the politics from the negotiations, all sides agreed to take advice on New Zealand's targets from an independent climate commission.

"If you have essentially your best and your brightest informed by science ... it's an easier place to have a conversation with your community than just playing partisan politics with them," Mr Muller said.

Mr Shaw said the opposition could have exploited a potentially divisive policy - agriculture contributes half of New Zealand's greenhouse gas emissions - but did not. "They are playing an absolute straight bat," he said.

New Zealanders, like Australians, have endured increasing extreme weather. These include a record hot 2016, droughts and a major forest fire last year.

"We've definitely had a lot more extreme rainfall events," Nava Fedaeff, a climate scientist with the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research, said.

Farmers, who have in the past objected fiercely to taxes on methane, appear more ready to accept the need to act. DairyNZ, for instance, has welcomed the prospect of emissions targets enshrined in legislation to give the sector "much needed certainty".

Trish Rankin, a dairy farmer managing 440 cows for a Maori-owned co-operative in the Taranaki region of the North Island, said climate action "needs to be apolitical".

Ms Rankin said New Zealand farmers realised their social licence depended on their being good custodians of the land.

Mr Shaw said one reason for the different response was that farmers - unlike Australian coal companies - had options.

"People are still going to want to eat in 30 years' time, so the question is what do you produce and how do you produce it - not whether or not you're going to produce food," he said.

"But in 30 years' time, you can pretty much guarantee no one in the world is going to use coal."

urn:contentItem:5HND-S7P1-JD3N-544N-00000-00Volunteers join frontline2015-12-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Volunteers join frontlineERIN PEARSON

MORE than 100 volunteer firefighters from the Geelong, Bellarine Peninsula and Surf Coast areas are winding down after fighting the Scotsburn fire, south of Ballarat.

The volunteers joined -career firefighters on the frontline and containment line areas during 12-hour shifts across the weekend.

The CFA said almost every available volunteer unit -between Ballarat and the Bellarine Peninsula was dispatched as the flames burnt through 4600ha and 12 homes.

The CFA labelled the Scotsburn fire "under control" late Sunday, while crews in Lorne were still working last night to control a bushfire there.

A DEPI spokesman said firefighters would still be near Lorne today, to "fully track" the edges of the fire and control occasional flare ups. "It's not freely burning, not a raging forest fire," he said last night. "It's not really causing any great concert but the main thing is it's in inaccessible terrain." District 7 CFA duty officer Ian Bewick said strike teams on the weekend had been dispatched to the Meredith football ground.

"It was good work done by our guys," he said. "It was lucky it was on a weekend and we had a good number who could go and had strike teams -already in place due to pre-planning, so they were able to respond fairly quickly." Stonehaven volunteer Jeff Harriott said his team was fighting a fire at Fyansford on Saturday shortly before it was told to head west.

"When we finished containing that and mopping up we saw smoke in the Elaine direction," he said. "It wasn't long after that the call came through and you could tell from a distance it was big." Belmont CFA volunteer Nick Wojcik said he fought with a strike team from the southern side of the fire.

"It was great to see so many go away from their families and jump on a fire truck to go out and help," he said. "Nearly every brigade in district 7 was there."Emergency Services Minister Jane Garrett said the Scotsburn fire was the fastest locals had ever seen. "There's been about $30,000 already paid to people who've been -directly affected by this fire," she said. "I've also activated the ---re-establishment grants, which are up to $32,000 per household if a house has been -destroyed."

urn:contentItem:56J9-10N1-F0JP-W30X-00000-00Uphill battle feared2012-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisPg. 5Uphill battle fearedJESSICA TAYLOR<br/>taylorje@qst.newsltd.com.au

AUTHORITIES will be on high alert across the Caboolture region today as high temperatures increase the fire danger.

The forecast is for a maximum temperature of 30C, with a high forest fire danger.

And the bushfire season forecast from firefighters is bleak.

Queensland Fire and Rescue Service area commander Simon Ball said a high volume of dead tree limbs, dry grass and leaf litter was concerning.

``At some point it's going to burn . . . rain will not help in the long term,'' he said.

Mr Ball said the excessive rainfall over the past three years and shorter and wetter fire seasons, had boosted the fuel load.

He said locations that were most at risk of a bushfire were areas with hills and dry grass.

Mr Ball reminded the community to have a fire permit to light a fire bigger than 2m and encouraged people to visit ruralfire.qld.gov.au for tips on how to prepare for bushfire season, which usually ran until November.

To reduce the risk, the QFRS has conducted hazard reduction burns.

Between May and December the council has 30 hazard reduction burns planned.

urn:contentItem:56FM-VBW1-F0J6-J0NJ-00000-00THE Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre2012-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 5THE Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre

THE Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre (CRC) has painted a frightening picture of the summer ahead.

Almost all of the expansive and currently lush grasslands west of the ranges are set for above-normal fire activity in 2012-13 according to its latest fire forecast.

The forecast was released on Tuesday after extensive consultation and a meeting between fire managers, scientists and the Bureau of Meteorology at Rural Fire Service (RFS) headquarters in Lidcombe last week.

But the predictions of potentially disastrous grass fires in the west of the State are just the start of the threat which NSW faces this summer, said RFS Deputy Commissioner Rob Rogers.

"The point is each and every year there is a risk of forest fire danger in those typically forested areas," he said.

"What there hasn't been ? because of the drought for more than a decade ? was that grass fire danger. So we've still got the forest fire risk but we've also now got significant grass fire risk due to the record rainfall over the last couple of years.

"It's an expansive area that now has so much grass growing on it... some areas are carrying a lot of fuel."

The seasonal outlook paints a bleak picture with much of southern Australia ? particularly NSW, Western Australia and South Australia facing an above-normal fire season.

While Victoria is expected to experience normal activity, southern Queensland is also facing an above-average fire season.

Mr Rogers said there was potential for disastrous consequences in western parts of NSW this summer, with many people having not experienced the last major western grass fires of the 1970s and '80s.

"People underestimate just how devastating grass fires can be. They travel at a frightening rate, can jump ahead of themselves at incredible speed and they can be very, very dangerous," he said.

Mr Rogers said the RFS was conducting hazard reduction burns and working with councils to install strategic fire breaks and ensure key roads were up to a high standard.

A fortnight ago the RFS took the unprecedented step of taking senior volunteers from brigades east of the ranges on a tour through the western grasslands.

Mr Rogers said these volunteers would be the basis of any strike teams, should they need to be assembled during the fire season.

"They will be the key people if we need to send groups out west... to make sure they're there to provide a kind of induction for crews coming from the coast, because they have been out there in calm times, seen what some of the issues are and heard from some of the locals about particular fire hazards they have in their particular area," he said.

"What we've got to do is make sure we use those people that have that knowledge and combine them with locals, just to make sure that crews that get sent in from outside do the best they can as far as helping what the locals need, but also keeping themselves safe."

Mr Rogers said given Victoria was not facing an above-average season, the RFS would not be "too proud" to ask for assistance from the Country Fire Authority.

Bushfire CRC chief executive officer Gary Morgan said the purpose of the seasonal outlook ? which assesses the fire potential based on previous rainfall and fires and climate outlook ? was to provide fire managers with the best, up-to-date fire information.

"We provide this so that each of the State and territories can actually know what the threat is likely to be for the bushfire season and then do their planning accordingly to manage their threat," Mr Morgan said.

"It enables them to know not only whether they've got a potential problem or not in their jurisdiction, but whether their adjoining neighbours have got a potential problem."

urn:contentItem:5VVM-HCH1-F0J6-J1CF-00000-00Concern over feral pig spread2019-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Concern over feral pig spreadAndrew Miller

Victorian land managers and farmers in the south-west say they are concerned feral pigs are moving east into the Warrnambool area.

Forest Fire Management Victoria far south-west district manager Mark Mellington said data indicated that the population of feral pigs, and their distribution, was increasing.

Mr Mellington said authorities were hoping to contain feral pigs, where they were already established, while eradicating new populations.

"A stakeholder group has been established with local agencies and businesses to examine reported sightings and damage caused by feral pigs," he said.

"This collaborative approach will increase our understanding of the pigs' behaviour and impacts and determine future control options across public land."

He said trapping programs began on public land in 2015 and would continue, along with regular patrols and monitoring, this year.

Since trapping programs started, 208 feral pigs had been caught, including 123 sows and 85 boars.

New feral pig populations had been identified on public and private land in the south-west, including areas around Heywood, Portland, Dartmoor and Casterton.

Animal Control Technologies strategic commercial manager Craig Louey said his company supplied a commercial bait PIGOUT, a 1080 based poison, and was working on another one, HOGGONE.

"The pigs breed quite quickly if there is a food source and water," Mr Louey said.

"They can breed twice a year, producing up to 10 piglets."

Mr Louey said his company had been working on feral pig control for more than a decade.

"You need to use ongoing baiting programs, you can't just throw it out in the field one day, and expect to see dead pigs," he said.

He said the south-west's feral pig population may have come from escaped domestic animals.

He had also heard, anecdotally, hunters may have released them illegally.

Pigs could do tremendous damage to all types of farming activities.

"They will take newborn lambs, they will eat them, they can run through wheatfields, just rolling around and flattening them, not just eating the wheat, but flattening it," he said.

He said while biosecurity was tight in Australia, feral pigs could be a vector for transferring such diseases as African swine fever into the domestic industry.

Agriculture Victoria Established Invasive Animals biosecurity manager Jason Wishart said they were found throughout much of Victoria.

"They cannot be eradicated from the state and require ongoing management," Mr Wishart.

Agriculture Victoria monitored feral pig populations, across Victoria, which contributed to an understanding of trends and distribution.

It didn't undertake on-ground feral pig control programs, as it was not a land manager.

Basalt to Bay Landcare network facilitator Lisette Mill said there appeared to be evidence of pigs moving eastward.

"If the population is increasing, it will be moving across to colonise new territory, including the highly productive and important Basalt to Bay Landcare region, which starts on the edge of Moyne Shire," Ms Mill said.

"Feral pigs and farming are not conducive to each other; they bring massive biosecurity risks with them."

Ms Mill said tackling pigs involved the whole community, including crown land managers, Parks Victoria, councils, water authorities and farmers.

"As we come into autumn, pigs that have spent time in the bush, where they can get cover and food, start to move," she said.

"There's a point where the feed runs out, and they start to look for other places to find food."

She said pigs would also be seeking water sources, such as rivers, creeks and farm dams.

Tyrendarra beef and veal producer Phill Saunders said he had been having problems for about five years.

Mr Saunders estimated pigs could cause as much as $1000 damage a hectare to pasture land.

"You're looking at losing production for the winter and spring," he said.

"The ground doesn't grow much pasture after they've been through it, so you have at least drag and resow it.

"We tend to have smaller paddocks.

"When they come in, they can very quickly damage between eight and 10 hectares, in a pretty short time."

He was concerned that ships, coming into Portland, could bring foot and mouth disease.

Mr Saunders said he would like to see the Department of Agriculture take a lead role in controlling feral pigs, as chief veterinary officer Dr Charles Milne had extensive experience in dealing with foot and mouth disease.

"My rationale is pigs are the number one vector for foot and mouth, so we need one agency to take the lead role," he said.

Ron Millard, who runs sheep on a small block at Tyrendarra, said his property was close to a state forest.

He said he hadn't experienced stock losses, as the pigs appeared to have gone by lambing time.

But the pigs did extensive damage to paddocks.

"They didn't have far to go out of the bush and they did an awful lot of damage," he said.

"They rooted it all up, like you'd got in with a plough."

But he said it appeared last winter the population, living in the state forest, had been cleaned out by hunters.

"I had the authorities there," he said.

"They were out setting traps and cameras, but never had much success, probably because there were that many people with dogs coming out hunting the pigs."

urn:contentItem:4P89-SHY0-TXN5-V31D-00000-00Dunn's having fun in man's world1998-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 51Dunn's having fun in man's worldVictory makes hardship all worthwhile

It gets lonely in a shoebox-sized jockeys' room far away from the camaraderie of the blokes and svelte 22-year-old Kelly Dunn has more reason than most her age to watch her weight, but victory at Royal Randwick makes these small hardships worthwhile.

Women jockeys remain a minority and few would dispute it's an uphill battle for credibility and acceptance in one of the last real male bastions.

But when Dunn booted home another winner yesterday the number of high-profile trainers who knocked on the door of her quaintly named "lady" jockeys' room indicated a groundswell of support for the talented rider.

"It does get a bit lonely some days, up here in a box with a TV," said Dunn of the room she shares mostly with senior rider Lee Ann Olsen.

"And I do have to watch my weight as I am naturally about 53kg to 54kg and I try to ride at 50kg.

"I try to eat three healthy meals a day with lots of fruit, pasta, rice and vegetables.

"But I ride a winner at Randwick and that will make it all easy for the next month!"

The first-year apprentice has impressed trainer Geoff Maynes who has engaged her four times for three wins including yesterday's surprise victory aboard Forest Fire, her second on the gelding.

Dunn went very wide in the straight on the 15/1 chance to score the Alexander Mackellar Hcp (1400m) by a decisive 1-lengths from promising Sound (8/1), with well-supported 11/4 favourite Bound By Silence a further neck away third.

"I wasn't too happy about being that wide, but they weren't going to let me back in - there's no favours out there - and as it turned out I was on the best part of the track, and Forest Fire travelled beautifully all the way," Dunn said.

Dunn worked briefly as a teacher after graduating from university, but the long-time trackwork rider found the lure of racing irresistible and succumbed to trainer Paul Cave's apprenticeship offer last September.

Her first race ride resulted in a winner, at Kembla Grange on aptly named Exploding Success, and a mere week later, on September 21 last year, Dunn recorded her first city win aboard the Cave-trained Seto Stayer.

Illus: Jockey Kelly Dunn with trainer Paul Cave. Dunn scored a surprise victory with Forest Fire in the Alexander Mackellar Hcp at Randwick yesterday. Picture: BRADLEY PHOTOGRAPHERS.

urn:contentItem:57J1-W501-JC0X-K0Y3-00000-00VIC:Bushfire threatens towns in Vic's east2013-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Bushfire threatens towns in Vic's east

  BUSHFIRES VIC FACTBOX 3RD UPDATE
   LARGE BUSHFIRE THREATENING TOWNS IN VICTORIA'S EAST:
  
   * Fast-moving bushfire in Glenmaggie/Seaton area, about 200km east of Melbourne
   * About 48,000 hectares in size, out of control and creating spot-fires approximately 2-4km ahead
   * A man has died in the fire. Body found in burnt out vehicle in Seaton area at 5pm (AEDT) Friday
   * Now moving in a northeasterly direction in mainly forest country, but has been burning more like a grassfire than a forest fire
   * Impacting Lake Glenmaggie, Dawson, Heyfield (population 1937), Seaton (population 215) and Licola (population 29), where 10 residents remain.


   * CFA says four holiday homes or holiday shacks within national park have been destroyed. At least one home in Seaton confirmed destroyed, and possibly as many as four or five.
   * Four firefighters had to take shelter in their truck as the blaze passed over them but are OK
   * The township of Licola is isolated by fire. Sixty-one children and 15 adults evacuated from Licola Wilderness Village on Thursday night.
   * Fire started in the Baw Baw National Park near Aberfeldy on Thursday. Fire burned 950 hectares at 7pm (AEDT) on Thursday, overnight it reach 12,000 hectares, triple what authorities expected.
   * Friday was a total fire ban for West and South Gippsland, north east, northern country and East Gippsland districts.

urn:contentItem:5MJ8-CKR1-F0J6-J1GF-00000-00Fire in East Bendigo2017-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisFire in East Bendigo

UPDATE, 3.16pm: Bendigo Crime Investigation Unit members have arrived at the scene of a fire near Bendigo Airport.

Bendigo Fire Station senior station officer Darren Eenjes said the fire was being treated as suspicious.

"Witness accounts say people were seen throwing some sort of liquid into the bush and driving off with the fire starting shortly after," he said.

"It's a crime scene at the moment. DELWP are also here with two units and their operations manager and will be conduction an investigation with police.

"It's very frustrating and very dangerous."

CFA units received call at 1.25pm for a grass and scrub fire threatening houses in McDowalls and Victa Roads.

"Further information made us upgrade the response and call in two extra appliances," Senior Station Officer Eenjes said.

He said it took units 15 minutes to control.

"Fire was spreading from McDowalls Road to a house on Victa Road. We made sure to position our first truck to protect that asset," he said.

"We used three appliances, two from Bendigo and one from Golden Square, and 15 firefighters to contain the fire to one paddock."

Staff at the RSPCA in Piper Lane were informed of the fire but did not need to take any precautionary measures.

UPDATE, 2.45pm: Victa Road has been re-opened following a fire near Bendigo Airport.

The fire is being treated as suspicious.

CFA and police fire investigators are on scene.

Staff at the nearby Mulligrub's Play Centre said the fire did not escalate to a point where they were forced to evacuate the business.

"Once the CFA arrived, they controlled the fire very quickly," a staff member said.

"After that, it was more exciting for the kids to see the firefighters across the road."

Police are speaking to witnesses at Mulligrub's, who were in the area when the fire started.

Mulligrub's staff said there was a fire in the same area last summer.

UPDATE, 2.24pm: Fire investigators are at the scene of a blaze near Bendigo Airport.

Firefighters are continuing to black out the paddock.

EARLIER: Firefighters are at the scene of a fire near Bendigo Airport, which is believed to have been deliberately lit.

The fire is in a building site at Mcdowalls Road, East Bendigo, near the intersection with Victa Road.

Authorities are investigating after finding a plastic bottle containing petrol at the scene.

About five Country Fire Authority units are responding.

Forest Fire Management Victoria, and police are also on scene.

The fire is under control, but smoke might be visible in the area.

There is no threat to surrounding buildings or communities.

The CFA has advised people to stay informed and monitor conditions, and to keep the roads clear for emergency services to respond.

Victa Road is blocked and north-bound traffic is being directed down Mcdowalls Road.

Traffic from Rohs Road is being turned back.

urn:contentItem:54N9-J6G1-JD67-100G-00000-00SANTIAGO. Chilean President Sebastian Pinera2012-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisPg. 18SANTIAGO. Chilean President Sebastian Pinera

SANTIAGO. Chilean President Sebastian Pinera says six people have died in the forest fire affecting the municipality of Carrahue, 700 kilometres south of Santiago, and he claimed that the outbreak of the fire itself was a terrorist act. "We have reliable information that causes us to presume that an international criminal has been behind these fires," said the president during an appearance before reporters at La Moneda Palace. "We must fight not only the fires but also the criminals who presumably are behind (them,)" Pinera said. After confirming that six firefighters were injured as they tried to extinguish the flames in Carahua, the president emphatically stated that "terrorist behaviour hides behind these deliberately caused fires". Pinera's accusations come after remarks made on Tuesday by Interior Minister Rodrigo Hinzpeter, who said that "political or economic aims" could be behind some of the fires raging in the southern part of the country. In the past, attacks have been registered in the Araucania region against the facilities of forestry firms which the government attributed to Mapuche Indian activists. However, on this occasion the authorities have not said who might be behind the allegedly intentionally-set fires.

urn:contentItem:57FR-JT11-JD3N-538F-00000-00A NATION ON ALERT2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6A NATION ON ALERT

NSW

FIREFIGHTERS were last night battling 135 blazes in 40-plus temperatures and ``catastrophic'' conditions.

THE fires have destroyed 66,000ha with 25 fires out of control.

EMERGENCY warnings were in place for five fires last night.

THE WORST fires were in the south of the state, near Cooma, Nowra, Bega and Wagga.

A FIRE in a transformer station of the Lucas Heights nuclear power station was contained.

TASMANIA

ABOUT 40 bushfires continued to burn across Tasmania, with uncontrolled blazes at Montumana in the northwest and Lake Repulse in the Derwent Valley.

RESIDENTS have been told to evacuate areas on the Tasman Peninsula.

THE NUMBER of properties lost was confirmed at 128.

A 22,000ha bushfire was burning out of control between Forcett and the Tasman Peninsula in southern Tasmania.

VICTORIA

A FIRE burning in Victoria's west, near Ballarat, destroyed at least two homes in Cheptsowe and was burning out of control last night.

A SLOW-MOVING bushfire has burnt about 9000ha near the SA border and was last night threatening the Victorian town of Dartmoor.

SA

A STRING of fires were burning across the Far North, but were not threatening property.

ACT

A FOREST fire is burning in the ACT's south, close to Mount Ginini in the western region of Namadgi National Park, but is under control.

QUEENSLAND

EIGHT bushfires were burning under control across Queensland and were not posing a threat to property.

urn:contentItem:5JKX-3151-F0N8-R35P-00000-00Late burst of good weather helps planned burns2016-04-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSLate burst of good weather helps planned burns

Planned burning across east Gippsland is making great progress thanks to a late burst of stable conditions, allowing Forest Fire Managers to get plenty of burns done to protect Gippsland communities.

Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Grange Jephcott said: 'Just a few weeks ago we thought weather conditions were going to limit our ability to get some key community protection burns done ' conditions were much too wet across most of Gippsland.'

'However, we've had this late burst of clear stable weather which looks likely to continue and we've been able to get some really important burns done around communities such as Orbost, Cabbage Tree Creek, Cann River, Bemm River, Noorinbee, Mallacoota, Tubbut, Bonang and Bendoc,' Mr Jephcott said.

'We hope in the next week or so we can also get some more protection burns done in the Cann River, Mallacoota and Bendoc areas.'

'You might see our crews out and about, particularly in the days prior to a burn program starting in your area, making sure people in your community know what is planned for the coming days.'

'We're really grateful for the assistance of the first Gunaikurnai crew on burns around the Bairnsdale area ' it's fantastic to see them taking part in burns on their country.'

'When planned burns are happening in your area you may see and smell smoke and some parks and roads may close. This week this may include closure of part of the East Gippsland Rail Trail and traffic management applied to the Princes Highway.'

For your health and safety, find out when planned burns are happening near you. Go to vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the FireReady app or call the Victorian Bushfire Information Line on 1800 240 667. The Planned Burns Notification System (PBNS) is an opt-in system and can send an SMS or email message prior to a burn being carried out and when it is in progress, in a region you subscribe to. To register go to vic.gov.au/plannedburn

The Chief Fire officer is currently the final approver of all planned burns. This measure is in place as DELWP changes its approach to risk management in response to the recommendations of the Lancefield-Cobaw Fire Investigation.

For more information go to: http://delwp.vic.gov.au/fire-and-emergencies

For more information on the Victorian Government's new approach to bushfire risk management go to http://www.delwp.vic.gov.au/safer-together

urn:contentItem:44J3-RR80-015G-P451-00000-00<published>2001-03-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:42:16Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 3</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firemen died near town in no danger</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Kristine Gough</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIVE volunteer firefighters died protecting a town that was never in serious danger, a damning report on the Linton bushfire has concluded.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The method of attack on the 1998 blaze was doomed to failure because the firefighters were generally inexperienced in forest blazes, says the report by four fire safety experts, commissioned by Victorian Coroner Graeme Johnstone.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "The firefighters showed little understanding of forest fire behaviour … and appeared to be largely using tactics more appropriate for suppressing grass fires," wrote Neil Burrows, Phillip Cheney, David Packham and Kevin Tolhurst.</p><p>The head-on attack on the fire, first mounted by tankers lined up along a road in the fire's path, was never going to succeed, the report says.</p><p> "Firefighters with any experience in forest fire suppression would have known that the fire could not be stopped on a narrow road, regardless of the fire tanker resources available."</p><p> Five Geelong-based Country Fire Authority volunteers -- Garry Vredeveldt, 47, Stuart Davidson, 28, Christopher Evans, 27, Jason Thomas, 25 and Matthew Armstrong, 17, on his first bushfire call -- died on December 2, 1998, when their empty tanker was incinerated by flames fanned by a sudden wind change. They were mopping up the eastern flank of a fire they thought was threatening Linton, apparently unaware of weather reports warning of an impending change.</p><p> The report, tendered this week to the Linton fire coronial inquest, concludes the threat to the historic mining township on that day was more assumed than real.</p><p> "It should have been immediately obvious that the green condition of the grasslands would contain the fire to forest fuels," it says.</p><p> The strike team containing the doomed tanker should not have been used on the eastern flank as their two-wheel-drive vehicles were unsuitable and there was little evidence the team was properly trained in forest fire fighting.</p><p> The report ends with strong criticism of falling Victorian government funding for the protection of public land from fire. The Department of Natural Resources and Environment has responsibility for fighting forest fires such as the Linton blaze.</p><p> Cost-cutting had forced land management agencies to rely too heavily on volunteer firefighters, it stated. "We believe this is putting an undesirable and excessive demand on the volunteers' time and effort, and putting them in life-threatening situations."</p><p>Wall of flames</p><p>About 8.45pm on December 2, 1998, the Geelong West fire crew was mopping up the fire's eastern flank. As crew members travelled down a narrow bush track to refill with water, a sudden wind change fanned a wall of flames that incinerated their tanker.</p><p> Their colleagues on the Geelong City tanker, 20m away, used their water reserves to create a fog around the vehicle, and thus survived.</p><p> The inquest into the deaths began in July 2000 and was originally expected to last 12 weeks.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5T7M-0P61-F0JP-W1HY-00000-00IN THE DANGER ZONE2018-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1IN THE DANGER ZONEBy PETER HUNT

EXCLUSIVE FUEL loads in Victoria's most populous and highest-risk bushfire zone have built up to almost the same levels as prior to the catastrophic 2009 Black Saturday fires.

The residual risk in the state's East Central zone, which covers 59 per cent of Victoria's population, has been climbing steadily since Black Saturday's fires on the back of massive forest regrowth. The zone's residual risk, which is mainly a measure of fuel loads, has climbed from 39 per cent in the aftermath of Black Saturday's fire storms to about 76 per cent today.

Just before Black Saturday the residual risk was measured at 81 per cent. Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief officer Chris Hardman said "a high-risk level meant communities needed to maintain awareness and readiness to enact their bushfire plan.

"A heightened seasonal outlook and high risk has also triggered FFMVic to bring forward preparedness activity to enable increased bushfire response and suppression.

"FFMVic has recruited over 650 seasonal project firefighters and brought forward servicing and investment in firefighting fleet and aviation resources. FFMVic also has aid arrangements in place to request interstate and international support if needed." More than 1800 homes and 159 people died in the King Lake-Marysville fire storms that swept across the state's East Central zone, leading to a Royal Commission recommendation: "the state fund and commit to implementing a long-term program of prescribed burning based on an annual rolling target of 5 per cent minimum of public land".

" Continued, Page 4 " Rule's View, Page 17 " From Page 1 That recommendation was never adopted, with a 2015 Victorian Inspector-General for Emergency Management review instead recommending a risk-based approach to mitigate major bushfire risks around key population centres.

The Royal Commission also recommended the then Department of Sustainability and Environment: "specify the characteristics of fire management zones - including burn size, percentage area burnt within the prescribed burn, and residual fuel loading", plus "report annually on prescribed burning outcomes in a manner that meets public accountability objectives â€¦ targets, area burnt (and) funds expended".

While the current measures of residual risk are based on fuel loads, it also models risks to homes and other assets.

When The Weekly Times asked for specific fuel load data, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's spokeswoman stated: "I've been advised that the fuel load data is only published to Business Level Data (an internal system), which means it is only available to internal DELWP users".

Dry conditions have made fuel reduction burns more challenging, with FFMVic struggling to meet its BURN targets.

"Challenges include the reduced opportunity to safely undertake fuel management given extended dry conditions, and the complexities of implementing planned burns in areas with significant population living in close proximity to forests and grasslands," Mr Hardman said.

"FFMVic prioritises its fuel management program to target high risk-reduction burns. Sixty per cent of these burns were delivered in autumn 2018, utilising all available windows of opportunity.

"Examples of some of these high risk-reduction burns include those targeting townships such as Cockatoo, Warburton, Emerald, Derrimut and Toolebewong." He said FFMVic also undertook mechanical fuel treatments such as slashing and mulching and these remained a priority in spring.

Meanwhile, two consecutive years of record low rainfall have left a large chunk of the East Central zone and East Gippsland in a tinder dry state, further reducing DELWP's opportunity to conduct fuel reduction burns.

"Extended dry conditions and high fire danger into April has reduced windows for planned burning in Gippsland," the DELWP spokeswoman said.

However, DELWP was able to conduct high-priority burns in autumn at Bemm River, Bruthen, Buchan, Omeo and Orbost.

East Gippsland Forest and Fire Planning regional manager Peter West said unusually early bushfire activity occurred in East Gippsland during July and August, highlighting the severe level of dryness in forests.

"These dry conditions are likely to be exacerbated during spring and summer, with the climate outlook for drier and warmer conditions. These areas can expect above normal fire potential from August right through summer." While East Gippsland's forests are dry the residual risk for the region is just 47 per cent, following a series of large fires across the region in recent years.

urn:contentItem:5X7F-1PK1-DXP7-12D3-00000-00It's only October, so what's with all these bushfires? New research explains it2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:16ZLexisNexisIt's only October, so what's with all these bushfires? New research explains itChris Lucas, Senior Research Scientist, Australian Bureau of Meteorology

Bureau of Meteorology researchers painstakingly analysed more than 40 years of data to work out exactly what is causing Australia's spring bushfire phenomenon.

Summer might be more than six weeks away, but out-of-control bushfires have already torn across parts of eastern Australia in recent days, destroying homes and threatening lives.

As of Wednesday afternoon, up to 30 homes were feared lost or badly damaged by bushfires burning in northern New South Wales. About 40 fires burned across the state.

This did not come as a surprise to meteorologists and fire agencies. Record-breaking heat and windy conditions were forecast for parts of NSW and Queensland this week, prompting severe fire danger ratings.

We're often told the Australian bushfire season is starting earlier. This year it began in September on the eastern seaboard. Last year and in 2013, significant spring fires hit NSW and in 2015 they affected much of the nation's southeast.

But what lies behind this phenomenon? We examined seasonal fire weather history for 44 years at 39 weather stations to find the precise answer.

This analysis is the most comprehensive ever conducted in Australia. It confirms the strength of the relationship between climate drivers such as El Niño, climate change, and the Australian bushfire season. It also demonstrates that a few milder bushfire seasons do not mean climate change isn't happening.

Hot, dry, windy conditions spell fire trouble

The prerequisites for a severe bushfire season are high temperatures, low humidity, and strong winds that coincide with long periods of low rainfall.

These weather ingredients are used to calculate an area's fire danger rating, using the Forest Fire Danger Index. The index produces a score reflecting the severity of fire weather on a given day, where zero represents minimal fire danger, 50 represents conditions where a fire ban may be issued, and 100 is considered potentially catastrophic.

Read more: Climate change is bringing a new world of bushfires

Loss of human lives and   property most often occurs on days when the index is high in a particular area. But strong seasonal fire weather doesn't always translate to high-impact fires. Other factors in play include terrain, vegetation, ignition and the weather on the day.

In our research, we analysed the strength of the worst fire weather conditions to understand the relative severity of fire weather during different seasons and years, in relation to various climate drivers.

Why is fire weather so different every year?

In Australia, the year-to-year changes in climatic conditions are largely driven by three factors: the El Niño Southern Oscillation, the   Indian Ocean Dipole, and the   Southern Annular Mode.

Each of these climate drivers involves either changes to sea surface temperatures, wind movements, or both. They can all can affect temperature and rainfall patterns across the Southern Hemisphere, including Australia.

Our research confirmed that across the continent over more than four decades, climate drivers have affected the variability of Australia's fire weather.

Read more: The phoenix factor: what home gardeners can learn from nature's rebirth after fire

Of these drivers, the El Niño Southern Oscillation is the most influential. Weather during an El Niño phase is typically hot and dry, leading to worse seasonal bushfire conditions.

The positive phase of the Indian Ocean Dipole often coincides with El Niño and exacerbates its effects. This phase generally results in lower than average rainfall across southern Australia.

But when these two climate modes are in a negative phase, our research confirms that Australia often experiences more rain and milder bushfire conditions.

The modes evolve over many months and their effects on fire weather persist for several seasons. Their state during winter and spring is a strong indicator for the rest of the fire season for much of Australia.

The Southern Annular Mode refers to the north-south movement of strong westerly winds in parts of the Southern Hemisphere. When the mode is in a prolonged negative phase, fire weather conditions in Australia are worse - particularly in NSW. This effect is pronounced in winter and spring and means less rainfall and strong westerly winds.

The 2019 winter saw a persistent negative Southern Annular Mode, as did the 2013 and 2018 winter and spring seasons. There was a strong El Niño event and positive Indian Ocean Dipole in 2015. Australia's bushfire season started earlier than usual in each of these years.

The converse is also true. In 2011 a strong La Niña (the opposite of an El Niño) resulted in milder bushfire seasons, as did the negative Indian Ocean Dipole of 2016.

Climate change is a culprit too

Long-term climate change in Australia is an undeniable reality. The State of the Climate 2018 report for Australia notes strong land surface temperature increases and a 10-20% decline in cool season rainfall across southern Australia since the 1970s. These changes are closely associated with increasing human greenhouse gas emissions, as well as natural variability.

The changed conditions has led to an average increase in the severity of seasonal bushfire weather across Australia - especially in southern parts of the continent. The increased severity affects all seasons but in particular spring, which means that, on average, the bushfire season is starting earlier.

Pulling it all together

Our research has made clear that climate modes bring large and rapid swings to the fire weather, while human-induced climate change gradually increases background fire weather conditions. The trend generally means an earlier start to the bushfire seasons than in the past.

Read more: Grim fire season looms but many Australians remain unprepared

Climate change is definitely playing a role in producing the earlier start to bushfire seasons and overall more extreme seasons, particularly in southeastern Australia. However, the natural variations in climate modes continue to play a key role, meaning we should not expect every bushfire season to be worse than the last as a result of climate change.

Similarly, a few milder bushfire seasons among a string of record high seasons does not mean that climate change should be dismissed.

Sarah Harris works for the Country Fire Authority.
